text: probably the biggest misconception about
CPR is that it's hard to do the reason
somebody will need CPR is because
they've gone to cardiac arrest so the
heart rhythm is not sustainable with
life and that can either be from a very
fast rhythm from the bottom of their
heart or it can be that there's been a
slowdown to stopping of their heart
we know that survival after cardiac
arrest is low and a big reason it's so
low is because people and bystanders
don't feel comfortable going and trying
to help for a long time CPR discussions
were evolved around the mouth-to-mouth
component of it and the American Heart
Association has walked away from that
aspect for bystanders so when you see
somebody collapse what you want to do is
once you realize that they're
unconscious go up to them and press in
the middle of the chest as hard and fast
as you can greater than hundred times a
minute and what you're doing is you're
actually giving the person a blood
pressure even transiently it's not as
much that people are doing something
wrong when they're trying CPR it's that
they don't step in to try we have to
keep in mind that when somebody's having
a cardiac arrest they essentially have
died so you're not hurting them what
you're trying to do is just get them
back or maintain blood supply of the
vital organs so I encourage everybody if
they're in that situation to try it
